titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Thanksgiving Day— I went with my wife, Catherine Johnson, and my youngest child, Charles, to my father’s, at Quincy. We attended at meeting, and heard Mr: Whitney, preach the approach of the Millennium, and false politics— We dined at my fathers, where were Mr: and Mrs: Cranch, my Aunt Smith—My brother Charles’s widow with her daughters, and all my family—we found both George and John unwell— We all returned in the Evening to Boston; and before the children were put to bed they were all sick.

2. A continuance of dull and uncomfortable weather— Our three children are all sick—John to a degree which greatly alarms us.— I called upon Dr: Eustis, and told him my determination, to take no part in the measure which he proposes— He appeared satisfied with my reasons, though he urged me with great earnestness to decide otherwise— At his request, I left with him the paper I had drawn up, with the condition agreed between us that it should be for his use alone; and to be returned to me, when sufficiently considered by him— I shewed it yesterday to my father; and as this is a case in which I thought faithful counsel would be prudent to take, I asked his advice— He declined however giving me any decided opinion— Between the magnitude of the prize, in the view of Ambition, and the magnitude of the Stake, in that of personal Independence, he was at a loss to decide for me, and left me to the operation of my own mind— For my own part, in this as in other cases, I set my ambition aside— The question is whether I shall assume an agency in this transaction, which shall make me the Candidate of the party, for the Governor’s Office at the next Election— By declining to act, I shall certainly not be taken up— By acting, in all probability I should— But my occupation, my support, the comfort of my family, and my father’s quiet, in his declining life, must be ventured upon the die; and after all, the public benefit, which might result from my decision, is quite uncertain— My only regard is to the public, and my own opinion, with that of my friend G. and the hesitation of my father, all concur to the same point in my final decision— Catherine attended this Evening a Ball at Mr: Apthorp’s— Mrs: Adams and myself sent an excuse, owing to the illness of our children—

3. I was confined to my house the whole day, by the foulness of the weather, and the illness of all the children— But in the Evening, I called upon Dr: Warren, to request that he would see John, and consult with Dr: Welsh upon his case— Dr: Welsh was here to see them— George, and perhaps Charles have the chicken-pox. John was again extremely unwell the whole day— I also called this Evening at the Athenaeum, but Mr: Shaw was not there.

4. The children continue all so unwell, that I only could go out— I heard Mr: Isaac Smith, at Mr: Emerson’s; in the forenoon— My brother, who had returned yesterday from Haverhill with his family came and dined with us— Job came in from Quincy for them, and they returned this Evening— Job lodges here— Dr: Warren and Dr: Welsh came this afternoon, and consulted respecting the State of our child John— They encourage us to hope, that his situation is not so alarming as we apprehended— He seems this day rather better, than for the last three days— I called this Evening, and paid a visit of about an hour to Mrs: Quincy.

5. At my Office— Letters from Mr: Parker, Senator U.S. from New-Hampshire, and from Mr: Cook of H.R. I saw Dr: Eustis, who proposes to make more use of my paper, that I had intended— But I see no reason for withdrawing it— Some business, in my professional course— Catherine spent the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s, where there was a party, and where I was engaged; but was prevented from going by Mr: De Grand’s coming in, and spending the Evening with me. Mrs: Adams stayed at home with the children— John continues apparently better.

6. Morning at my Office, and wrote to Mr: Parker the Senator from New-Hampshire— George and Charles have still the chicken-pox— Charles is quite ill with it— John continues apparently; and we hope really better— Part of this Evening at Mr: Shaw’s Office— Resumed the study of French with George.

7. This is the day upon which by the Constitution and Laws of the United States, the Election is made of the President and Vice-President, for the four years ensuing the 3d: of March next— The Electors for this Commonwealth met in this town, and voted for C. C. Pinckney, and R. King.— Forenoon at my Office— Club this Evening at Dr: Elliots, very thinly attended— The Season is becoming severe— I found my thermometer this morning at 10. degrees above 0.

8. Letters from Mr: Cook, and Dr: Mitchill at Washington— Answered the former— Met Mr: Jackson the Treasurer of the College and called at his house— Catherine Johnson went to the Ball this Evening;—with Mrs: Otis & Mr: C. Foster. Our children are still unwell— But we hope, recovering— Mr: W. Tudor junr: called at my Office this morning, concerning a claim of Madame de Vaudreuil on the United States.

div.p: 9. Mrs: Quincy called on a visit to Mrs: Adams this Morning— I walked to Cambridge just in Season, to attend the declamation which was short— At 3. I read my 8th: Lecture; and immediately afterwards walked home. The weather continues very cold— Evening at home; chiefly idle; my own studies being suspended by the weakness of my eyes; and my son George’s, by a severe cough, which the chicken-pox has left upon him— The children are still all unwell.

10. Forenoon at my Office; still engaged in writing letters— Job came in with a Chaise from Quincy this afternoon, and I went out to my father’s with my son John— George is confined to the house with a severe cough.— The Governor of this Commonwealth, James Sullivan, died about 6. O’Clock this morning.

11. Heard Mr: Whitney, morning and afternoon. Remainder of the day confined to the house by the weather— My Mother has a rhumatic cough, which confines her to her chamber— I had conversation both with him and her, respecting certain domestic pecuniary concerns.

12. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage, with John— Mr: B. Welles called upon me, with a request from the family of the late Governor Sullivan that I would draw up an obituary notice of his character for publication; to which I assented— I wrote to Mr: Giles— Received letters from Mr: Anderson and Mr: Cook— These correspondences, and the rumours utterly destitute of foundation, circulated for particular purposes, respecting me, have a tendency to unsettle my mind, and to dissipate my attention from those occupations upon which it ought to be perseveringly bent. Let me hope I may not be too much diverted from the real purposes of my present life, nor suffer my feelings to be sported with, or my imagination to be deluded, by the electioneering intrigues of any party— In the dreams of other fancy’s, may the reality of my own situation still be present to myself, and teach me the steady possession of myself.

13. I was engaged great part of the day, writing the paper requested by Mr: Welles and also a letter to Dr: Mitchill— Charlotte Welsh dined with us; and the Dr: with his family pass’d the Evening here— Mr: Everett, Mr: Loud and Mr: White were also here. Had some consultation with Mr: Hall, on a question referred to us by the insurance office.

14. Further conversation with Mr: Hall— Roughly finished a biographical sketch of the late Governor— Mr: Tudor called upon me again— Mr: B. Joy and Mr: Peck informed me that the Gentlemen who proposed to employ me to argue their cause before the Supreme Court of the United States at Washington, had determined to accede to my propositions, and wished to consider me as engaged— Mr: Peck in the afternoon was at my Office— I called in the Evening, at Mr: B. Welles’s lodgings, and left the paper he had desired— Afterwards at Mr: Shaw’s Office— Club at Mr: Emerson’s in his new house— Mr: Hawley was there as a guest.— Mrs: Adams was very unwell the whole day— The Children also continue quite ill— John, appears better. But George and Charles have very troublesome and obstinate coughs—

15. At my Office both parts of the day— Writing letters and conversing with Mr: Hall— Evening, latter part at home— I have been two Nights mostly deprived of rest by the illness of our youngest child, Charles, which has for several days been encreasing

16. We were up almost the whole Night, with our child whose illness has become alarming— Mrs: Adams found it necessary at last to give him an emetic, which gave him some little relief; but his fever continues increasing— Dr: Welsh
attended him this morning— Towards Evening his fever became so high, that another remedy was resorted to, with considerable effect— My father and mother came to town this Morning.— My father and myself attended the funeral of the late Governor Sullivan which was attended with the solemnities usual on like occasions, and by a great concourse of People— The procession commenced between one and two O’Clock, and ended about four. I walked with Mr: S. Dexter— My father and mother dined with us, and stay with us untill to-morrow

17. I pass’d the Night with John; and Catherine took my place in the sick chamber— The child had a violent fever the whole Night, and the greatest part of this day— A Blister upon his breast was finally applied, and appears in some degree to relieve him— My father and mother, dined at Mr: W. Smith’s; and returned this afternoon to Quincy, taking with them our son George, who continues with a severe cough— I was at my Office morning and afternoon— But the condition of my child disqualifies me, for any occupation of business— Mr: De Grand pass’d the Evening with me.

18. Heard Mr: Lowell this morning at Mr: Emerson’s— Afternoon at Brattle-Street, where Mr: Buckminster delivered an excellent funeral Sermon, on the late Governor Sullivan— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 157 and 158— The child continues extremely ill; and this day has been under the operation of a mercurial pill.

19. Charles had a very restless and uneasy Night; so that we had scarcely any repose through the whole Night ourselves— His cough is yet very oppressive, and his fever very high— I attended morning and afternoon at my Office; and commenced the perusal of the papers in the case upon which I am to go to Washington— Let no neglect or indolence deduct from the sum of exertion which I can apply to this case— I called at Shaw’s Office, and found some letters for me there.

20. The child had rather a better Night— His fever abates; but his cough continues as severe as it has been yet— I suffer for him a degree of anxiety, beyond expression, and beyond what I can justify to my own mind— I have however this day, begun to recover the power of attention, to business in which I am engaged— Was at my Office Morning and afternoon— Called in the Evening at Mr: Shaw’s where I met Mr: Buckminster—with whom I had some conversation relating to his Sermon and its subject— Mr: Boardman at the Insurance Office, engaged me to attend to a Cause of his, in the Supreme Court at Washington.

21. Charles continues so ill with his cough in the Night, that our rest is very much broken; and it now occasions a large intrenchment upon my morning hours— I rose this morning between 8 and 9— I now attend at my office regularly morning & afternoon. My correspondence employs much of my time—I fear, to little purpose— Attended the Club this Evening at Mr: Edward Gray’s— Almost all the members were there—

22. The illness of my child has overthrown the whole regular course of my occupations— And Mrs: Adams is now herself very unwell; owing to the fatigues and anxiety which she has undergone with him, for the last ten days— At my Office I am pursuing the enquiry, on the two causes for which I am engaged at Washington— But I must apply to them with another sort of vigour, or it were better for me to stay at home— I this day barely read through Mr: Boardman’s papers.

div.p: 23. I call’d at my Office— Rode to Cambridge, with a young Gentleman whose name I knew not. Saw the President, and informed him, that I should be absent at the beginning of the next term, and probably untill the close of the Month of March— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation at 2.— Read my Lecture 9. at 3. and immediately afterwards walked home— Called at Mr: Shaw’s Office, for a few minutes and afterwards at my own; where I found a letter from Mr: Giles, and his Speech in reply to Mr: Pickering; with some other letters— Evening at home; the child being still very sick; and his mother confined the whole day to her bed.

24. Forenoon at my Office— Afternoon and Evening at home, with my wife and child— Mrs: Adams was this day rather better; and the child remains with a very oppressive cough— I was myself also somewhat unwell. Of course I have this day done Nothing, of any kind of business.

25. I went with Catherine morning and afternoon to the chapel Church; and heard Christmas Sermons, from Mr: Freeman, and from his Colleague elect, Mr: Cary, who is to be ordained there next Sunday afternoon— Mr: Freeman spoke to me of him, and appears very anxious for his success— I went with Catherine to Dr: Welsh’s, and called there for her again at the close of the Evening— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 159. and 160—on repentance and confession— Mr: J. Gardner called at my house and I walked with him— Mrs: Adams took a ride this afternoon with the sick child; who seems a little better— His brother John has had yesterday and this day a return of his complaint; so that we form a mere hospital.

26. I delivered this morning to Mr: James H. Foster the Treasurer of the Neponset Bridge Company, Mr: Quincy’s Note to them. Pass’d the day principally at my Office, and read over again some papers relative to the Georgia-Land claims— Evening at home, and somewhat unwell.— A considerable fall of Snow—

27. Day at my Office— Wrote to Mr: Giles; and read a little on my business at Washington— Requested of Mr: Peck, and Mr: Joy further papers on the subject— Latter part of the Evening at home— We had been invited to Mrs: S. A. Otis’s, but sent an excuse— I went to bed quite unwell.

28. My brother and his wife came this morning to town— He dined with us— I attended at my Office; but to no purpose— I suffered with the rhumatism so severely, that I had no sleep last Night, and have been this whole day very much indisposed— Attended club this Evening at Dr: Howard’s— Only five other members there.

29. Pass’d the day principally at my Office, and began to pay some attention to my business— Evening at Mr: Shaw’s Office, in a pleasant conversation with Mr: J. Lowell— Catherine went with Miss H. Otis and our neighbours the Foster’s to a Ball at Dr: Danforth’s— My examination of my business, is not very encouraging. Mr: Jos: Hall was at my Office.
30. Day, and part of the Evening at my Office, examining my papers— My youngest child continues very unwell; confined to the chamber; and my wife is also much indisposed.
31. This afternoon my son George returned from Quincy where he has been spending a fortnight; and I went out to my father’s with John.— The former part of the day, I was engaged at my business.

Day. The sickness in my family, the severity of the Season, and the business upon which I am engaged have entirely changed the course of my occupations.— I now rise, seldom earlier than 8 O’Clock— After warming my chamber I read and write there untill 10— Breakfast— Attend at my Office about 11. and untill 1/2 past 1. Call at the Insurance Office to read the papers dine about 3.— Return to my Office, and read or write untill 7. or 8.— home again— Remainder of the Evening with my wife and children.

The year which has now closed has been among the most eventful of my life— It has removed me altogether from public life, and placed me in public consideration far behind that station to which I had attained— I have the approbation only of my own conscience, and the conviction upon my own mind, of having done my duty at every hazard— My private concerns have suffered in proportion to those of the public, and are already under no small embarrassment, with a prospect far more gloomy than their present condition— Yet under these Circumstances I look with confidence to that superintending power who from evil can bring forth good; and trust that whatever fate is destined to myself, the mercies of Heaven are still reserved for my family and my Country— His Will be done—
